title: Collection terminology is inconsistent
body:
The docs for the collections in `std` are inconsistent with their terminology. This sometimes affects argument names as well.

The maps use `key` and `value` consistently, but vary otherwise. For example, `BTreeMap` has:
- [`insert`](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.insert): "Inserts a **key-value pair** from [_sic_] the map."
- [`iter`](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.iter): "Gets an iterator over the **entries** of the map."
- [`len`](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.len): "Return the number of **elements** in the map."

When describing the key and value together, I think we should use `key-value pair`, because `element` is vague (do the key and value _each_ count as an element?) and because `entry` is too easily confused with the `Entry` API. However, `entry` should continue to be used to refer to instances of `Entry`.

The sets also vary. In addition to uses of `element` and `value`, `BTreeSet` has ["Gets an iterator over the BTreeSet's **contents**."](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.BTreeSet.html#method.iter)

Finally, in addition to uses of `element` and `value`, `BinaryHeap` has ["Returns the greatest **item** in the binary heap, or `None` if it is empty."](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.BinaryHeap.html#method.peek)

I think we should use `element` or `item` for all sets, lists, and queues, because `value` is already part of map terminology.

This will likely become easier to maintain once we get generic collection traits.
